H0.text: Which noted woman from the Caribbean tended wounded soldiers during the conflict. Nanny of the Maroons

H1.text: Which noted woman from the Caribbean tended wounded soldiers during the conflict. Louise Bennett-Coverley

H2.text: Which noted woman from the Caribbean tended wounded soldiers during the conflict. Audrey Jeffers

H3.text: Which noted woman from the Caribbean tended wounded soldiers during the conflict. Mary SEACOLE

A4.text: During the Crimean War, Seacole served hot tea and lemonade to cold, suffering soldiers awaiting transport to hospital on the wharf at Balaclava.

A5.text: Historians maintain that claims dismissing Seacole's work as mainly 'tea and lemonade' do a disservice to the tradition of Jamaican 'doctresses', such as Seacole's mother, Cubah Cornwallis, Sarah Adams and Grace Donne, who all used herbal remedies and hygienic practices in the late eighteenth century.
